sections.text:
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
Bioactivity of nanomaterials largely depends on its size, shape and crystalline nature. In
this work, the smaller sized spherical shaped nano-zirconia (ZrO2 NPs) (of ~ 9 to 11nm) was fabricated and studied its biological activity especially antioxidant and cytotoxicity against human colon carcinoma (HCT-116) and human lung carcinoma (A-549) cell lines. To have its real applications in biological aspects readily available Eucalyptus globulus (E. globulus) leaf extract was used as an effective capping and reducing agent for its synthesis. The prepared ZrO2 NPs was characterized by using different sophisticated instrumentations such as UV-Visible spectrophotometer, XRD, FTIR, TEM, SAED, EDX, DLS and fluorescence spectroscopy. Cellular mitochondrial activity i.e. cell viability was measured by MTT assay and anti-oxidant activity was determined by DPPH assay. The smaller sized ZrO2 NPs showed strong antioxidant activity as well as cytotoxicity on human cancer cell lines. Comparative cytotoxic studies were conducted on human cancerous cell lines using different techniques. Results confirmed the efficient anti-cancer activities of the fabricated ZrO2 NPs towards the tested cell lines as well as efficient anti-oxidant activity. This is the first study in which E. globulus leaf extract was used to synthesize smaller spherical shaped ZrO2 NPs for improved bioactivity i.e. antioxidant and cytotoxicity.
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
Keywords: Nano-zirconia, Green synthesis, Eucalyptus globulus leaf extract, antioxidant, cytotoxicity.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION:
sections.text:
Environmentally friendly nano regime materials were developed for the past few years
with the aim of low-cost production using simple green technologies. Nano zirconia (ZrO2 NPs) are widely used in various photocatalytic, piezoelectric applications, as a catalyst in various organic reactions [1] and industries for ceramics, dental and optical coatings [2,3]. The cytotoxic activity of nanoparticles mainly depends on its size and shape [4, 5]. Various chemical methods such as solvothermal method, hydrothermal method [6-10], aqueous precipitation method [11], sol-gel method [12-14], thermal decomposition methods [15-17] and pyrolysis of zirconium oxychloride salt organic precursors have been applied to prepare ZrO2 NPs [18]. These methods are more effective for the controlling the shape and size of nanoparticles but often results in the formation of mixed crystal phases [19-21]. However, all these methods require high temperature, costly and environmentally hazardous chemical precursors during synthesis processes [22,23].
Green synthesis has been adopted nowadays as the best alternative to the above-
mentioned methods to synthesize nanomaterials because these methods are simple, fast and environmentally safety procedures. Reports based on this energy sustaining process are very less. Bansal et al. reported the biosynthesis of ZrO2 NPs by using fungus Fusarium Oxysporum at neutral p H
[24]. Phytosynthesis (plant extract based) of ZrO2 NPs was first reported by
researchers using Curcuma longa tuber extract [25]. Researchers have performed the cytotoxicity of ZrO2NPs [5,26], but as per our knowledge, no cytotoxicity study for green synthesized ZrO2 NPs is available in the literature.
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
In the present work, first time we reported green synthesized Nano zirconia with smaller
size range using leaf extract of Eucalyptus globulus (E. globulus). Also, its anti-oxidant activity was monitored by using DPPH (1, 1, Diphenyl-2-picryl hydrazyl) assay and cytotoxic efficiency was studied by MTT (3-(4, 5-dimethylthiazol-2- yl)-2, 5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) assay against cancer cell lines such as human colon carcinoma (HCT-116) and human lung carcinoma (A-549) cell lines. 2.0 Experimental 2.1 Materials:
Fresh leaves of E. globulus were collected during the spring season at University of
Hyderabad (UOH), School of Chemistry, and Hyderabad. Zirconium oxychloride (ZrOCl2.8H2O), MTT (3-(4, 5-dimethylthiazol-2- yl)-2, 5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide), DPPH (2, 2 Diphenyl 2-picryl hydrazyl), all other chemicals required and solvents were of analytical grade and purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Bangalore, India). All reagents and solvent were used as-procured without any further purification. Millipore water was used throughout the experiment. A-549 Human lung carcinoma cell lines and HCT-116 human colon carcinoma cell lines were purchased from ATCC (NCCS, Pune, Maharashtra and India) for this study. 2.2 Preparation of Extract:
Freshly collected leaves were washed 2-3 times with running tap water followed by
Millipore water and dried at room temperature for sufficient time in a dust-free chamber. Fully dried leaves were grinded by electric mixer. 10 g of dried powder was taken in 100 ml of Millipore water and kept in a water bath for boiling at 80˚C for 2 h and a light yellow colored solution was formed. The formed solution was filtered, centrifuged and the obtained supernatant was stored at refrigerator at 4˚C to prevent microbial contamination for further use.
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T

sections.heading: 2.3 Synthesis of Zirconia (ZrO2) nanoparticles:
sections.text:
0.16 g salt was dissolved in 50 ml of double distilled water to prepare 0.01N of Zirconium
oxychloride (ZrOCl2.8H2O) solution. 50 ml of E. globulus extract was added to Zirconia precursor solution in equal ratio (1:1 v/v) by dropwise addition of extract with the aid of a peristaltic pump under vigorous stirring for 2-3 h. The dark, yellow color solution was formed and centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 15 min. Finally, the solution was washed with ethanol twice to eliminate any impurities present in the solution and the black colored precipitate was dried at 80˚C temperature keeping inside hot air oven. Finally, the black color amorphous powder was annealed at 600˚C for 3h in a muffle furnace to prepare crystalline ZrO2 NPs. 2.4 Characterization techniques:
The synthesized crystalline powder was analyzed by Powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD,
SMART Bruker D8 Advance X-ray Diffractometer) irradiated with Cu Kα radiation (λ= 1.54A˚) and the 2θ angle from 20-90˚ to determine crystallinity and phase purity. Surface morphology and elemental composition were observed by Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) fitted with Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) (FE-SEM, Carl-Zeiss model ultra-microscope 55, Germany) using acceleration voltage of 30 KeV electron beam). To observe electron diffraction patterns (EDP) selected area electron diffractions (SAED) patterns were recorded by using Transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with Gatan CCD camera and images were taken on FEI-make electron microscope TECNAI G2 S-Twin operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 Kev. To identify the particle size distribution and stability of NPs dynamic light scattering (DLS) experiment was done and Zeta potential was measured by using Horiba Scientific Nano Particii (SZ-100). Thermal analysis of black powder ZrO2 NPs before annealing was carried out by using Thermogravimetric analyzer (SDT-Q600) to determine the
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
weight loss of the nanoparticles against temperature. To identify the functional moieties, the metal–oxygen bond interactions was identified by using Attenuated Total Reflection-Fourier Transform Infrared spectrometer (ATR-FTIR Jasco-4100) at transmittance range from 4000- 400cm‾ 1 . UV-Visible and DRS (Diffuse reflectance) studies were done by using JASCO-V-670, Shimadzu) spectrophotometer to find out absorption intensity and band gap in the wavelength ranges of 200-800 nm. Photoluminescence (PL) study was done to observe emission wavelength by using fluorescence spectrophotometer (Hitachi, F-7000) at an excitation wavelength of 325 nm. 2.5 Cytotoxicity study of ZrO2 NPs 2.5.1 Cell Culture:
Two different human carcinoma cell lines - human lung carcinoma A549 and human
colon carcinoma HCT116 cell lines were procured from ATCC (NCCS, Pune, and Maharashtra, India). Cells were cultured in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle's Medium (DMEM) supplemented with penicillin (100 µg/mL), streptomycin (100 U/mL) and 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (FBS) maintaining in a humidified atmosphere at 37°C and 5% CO2. For exposure studies with ZrO2 NPs. HCT116 and A549 cells were seeded in appropriate cell culture flasks (T25 flasks, Tarson Inc., India) in DMEM/10% FBS one day prior to the exposure.

sections.heading: 2.5.2 Cell Viability (MTT assay):
sections.text:
To measure the cellular mitochondrial activity, MTT assay was employed by our old
method described elsewhere with minor modifications [27, 28]. Briefly, cells were seeded at 1×10 4 cells per well and incubated in DMEM containing 1% FBS with or without the test chemical for 24 h at 37°C, 5% CO2 and relative humidity more than 80%. After exposure, the test medium was discarded, and cells were incubated with 100 µL of MTT solution (0.5 mg/mL
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
MTT diluted in phenol-red free DMEM without FBS) for 1h at 37°C, 5% CO2. Subsequently, the MTT solution was discarded and 100 µL of DMSO was added to each well. Optical density (OD) of DMSO solution was read using ELISA reader at 550 nm (EL800, Bio-Tech Instruments, Inc.). Cell viability for each treatment was calculated as the ratio of the mean OD of replicated wells relative to that of the negative control (only cell culture medium and cells were added). It can be noted that the MTT assay was performed in 96 well plates for cell culture and similar to microbial toxicological evaluation positive control well, negative control well and experimental well were there. It can be noted that MTT assay has been performed for non-cancerous Vero cell line collected from African green monkey kidney epithelial cells. The absorbance values for experimental wells were compared with negative control by assuming cent percent growth of negative control. Alternatively, the cyto-toxicological property of ZrO2 NPs was compared with standard drug Cisplatin (CDDP) procured from Hi-Media, Bangalore, India. All the experiments were carried out in triplicate. The IC50 (value at which 50% cell death was observed) was calculated from the graph thus obtained.

sections.heading: 2.5.3 Cell mortality assay:
sections.text:
The cell mortality was evaluated by modified Trypan blue assay as described by [29] and
modified in our earlier studies [30]. Briefly, cells were plated in the 96-well plates (1 × 10 5 cells per well) and incubated for 24 h. Then, ZrO2 NPs was introduced to cells with different concentrations (same as used in cell viability test) in the culture medium. Cells cultured in the free medium were taken as the control. After 24 h, the supernatant was collected and the cells were detached with 300 µL trypsin–EDTA solution. The supernatant and detached cells mixture was centrifuged for 5 min at 1200 rpm. Then, the residue was dispersed in 800 µL Trypan blue solution. After 5 min of staining incubation, cells were counted using hemocytometer. The dead
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
cells were stained with blue color. Cell mortality (%) is expressed as a percentage of the dead cell number (or) the total cell number.

sections.heading: 2.5.4 Reactive Oxygen Species Generation:
sections.text:
Cell lines were cultured as mentioned above and treated with ZrO2 NPs for next 48 h.
One negative control was kept to compare with sample. The cultured cells were centrifuged at 4000 rpm at 4°C for 10 min to aspirate out the medium and cells were then re-suspended in phosphate buffer at pH 7.0. It can be noted that 10 mM DCFH2DA (2′, 7′- dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate), a weak fluorescent dye in methanol was diluted in culture medium to get 100 µM solution. The treated samples, as well as negative control, were treated with 100 µM DCFH2DA for 60 min. Next, centrifugation of the cellular suspension followed by removal of extracellular media to remove any excess DCFH2DA was carried out and further washed thrice to have clear readings. The fluorescence of oxidized green fluorescent 2′, 7′- dichlorofluorescein (DCF) was measured at an excitation wavelength of 492 nm and emission at 523 nm using a fluorescent spectrophotometer. Normally, DCFH2DA is more reactive with OH (hydroxyl) species in comparison with other reactive oxygen species (ROS).

sections.heading: 2.6 Antioxidant activity:
sections.text:
The antioxidant activity in the present study was carried out by using DPPH (1, 1,
Diphenyl-2-picryl hydrazyl) assay to determine the percentage of scavenging capacity [31]. In the present designed experiment, various concentrations (50, 100, 150, 200, 250 µg/mL) of the test sample ZrO2 NPs was dispersed in methanol and 1 mL of 1 mM DPPH was added to 3 mL methanol solution in small test tube and incubated at 37°C under dark conditions up to 30 min [32]. The color change from blue to yellow was observed and absorbance was recorded at 517 nm by using UV-Visible spectrophotometer. All the samples were tested in triplicate. In this
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
regard, DPPH • (unstable blue colour) liberates free radicals and ZrO2 NPs scavenges the free radicals and results in the formation of stable yellow colour DPPH molecule. Lower the absorbance value indicates the increasing free radical scavenging activity of the test NPs [33]. Percentage of inhibition values are compared by using absorbance values of standard ascorbic acid under identical conditions. 3.0 Results and Discussion 3.1 UV-Visible study:
Figure 1(a) represents the appearance of UV absorbance peak at 263 nm indicating the
formation of tetragonal ZrO2 phase [34]. UV-DRS (Diffuse reflectance spectrometer) spectrum (Fig. 1b) of ZrO2 NPs shows bandgap energy value as 3.15 eV which is calculated by using the following equation [35, 36].
1/ 2( ) /bulkc h E hv  
Where α is absorption coefficient, c is constant, hν is the photon energy and Ebulk is bulk
‘band gap. The optical band gap (Eg) obtained by the extrapolation of a Kubelka Munk plot on X-axis is shown in Figure 1(b). The energy band gap value confirms the semiconducting nature of the obtained ZrO2 NPs. Thus, UV-Visible spectrophotometric analysis suggests the formation of ZrO2 NPs. The size of the nanostructures was determined by microscopic as well as DLS techniques.

sections.heading: 3.2 Photoluminescence study:
sections.text:
Figure 2 signifies the formed ZrO2 NPs exhibiting photoluminescence peak at the
excitation wavelength of 325 nm (UV lamp source) and emission wavelength at 470 nm in the range of 400 to 580 nm. This phenomenon attributes the presence of defects due to oxygen vacancy in the monoclinic nanostructures. ZrO2 NPs exhibits prominent photoluminescence
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
activity at an excitation wavelength of 325 nm and its surface lattice defects are closely related with its size/shape i.e. crystallinity [37-39]. In addition, the photoluminescence results confirm the observations of UV-Visible spectroscopic results.

sections.heading: 3.3 X-ray Diffraction Analysis (XRD):
sections.text:
Figure 3 represents the obtained peaks at 2θ of 30.20 (101), 35.06 (200), 40.05 (110),
50.37 (202), 60.0 (313), 62.5 (222), 75.06 (400) which are indexed to the cell system tetragonal ZrO2 phase are compared with Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standard (JCPDS card number: 081-1544) as reported [19]. The average crystallite size of nanoparticles (diameter) is calculated by using Debye-Scherer equation [40,41] as
D = 0.89 λ/ (β cosθ),
Where λ is the wavelength of Cu Kα radiation (1.5406 A˚), β is full-width half maximum
(FWHM) of (111) plane and θ is diffraction angle. From the above Scherrer’s equation average crystallite size of ZrO2 is ~ 9.6 nm. The XRD result has confirmed the crystallinity and phase structure of ZrO2 NPs. 3.4 Dynamic light scattering (DLS) study: Figure 4(a) represents the dynamic light scattering (DLS) spectrum of the synthesized ZrO2 NPs exhibiting an average particle size of 10 nm. The average size of nanoparticles obtained from DLS is similar to the XRD and TEM results (Fig. 3). Figure 4(b) signifies the Zeta potential i.e. electrostatic stabilization value as -45.5 mV and this high Zeta potential value of nanoparticles suspension exhibits high anti-sedimentation capacity i.e. longer time stabilization of the dispersion. Stability of ZrO2 NPs was tested at a frequent time interval (30 to 180 days) and there was no significant peak shift in Zeta potential analysis. This report confirms that green
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
synthesized ZrO2 NPs are more stable and can be stored for a longer period of time, which can be further beneficial to industrial and biomedical applications.

sections.heading: 3.5 Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA):
sections.text:
Figure 5 signifies the thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) graph which represents the
percentage of weight loss of compound during the annealing at high temperature. As shown in TGA curve total two weight losses were observed. First weight loss occurred between 100°C to 180°C due to the loss of coordinated H2O molecule. Second major weight loss occurred at 460°C due to loss of terminal hydroxyl groups bonded to the surface of ZrO2 NPs and no further weight loss was observed after 500-800°C. There was no organic residue left over after annealing at above 500°C which was further confirmed by Infrared spectral study of the residual mass.

sections.heading: 3.6 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM – EDX) study:
sections.text:
The size range obtained from DLS (zeta-sizer) was confirmed with SEM results. Notably,
the absence of any impurity was analyzed by using SEM integrated with EDX. Figure 6(a) depicts the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images of synthesized ZrO2 NPs. The obtained images exhibit the formation of different morphology (i.e. spherical and rodshaped particles) and formed particles are highly dispersed. SEM integrated EDX analysis confirms the synthesized NPs containing elemental weight % of Zr (74.57%) and oxygen (25.43%) which specifies the higher purity of the synthesized ZrO2 NPs without any further impurities (Fig. 6b). It can be noted that absence of impurity was observed in earlier results i.e. thermal gravimetric analysis (Fig. 5). Furthermore, the size of the ZrO2 NPs was confirmed by TEM and HR-TEM analysis. 3.7 Transmission electron microscopy study:
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis of ZrO2 NPs exhibits particles are
spherical shaped and mean particle size ranges between 9-11 nm (Figure 7a and 7b) which closely supported the size calculated from X-ray diffraction by using Scherrer’s equation and SEM micrographs. Figure 7(c) reveals the d-spacing of two lattice planes as 2.90 Aº which is characteristic to ZrO2 NPs. Figure 7(d) indicates the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of ZrO2 NPs confirming its polycrystalline nature and arrangement of particles in respective of their unit cell plane structure are in close agreement to monoclinic. The cell structure exactly matches to the obtained XRD pattern of arrangement of peak hkl values and cell parameters (Fig. 3).

sections.heading: 3.8 Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) study:
sections.text:
Figure 8(a) represents the FTIR spectrum of E. globulus leaves extract which consist of
various functional groups such as peak at 1018 cm -1 for C-N stretching of aliphatic amines, 1409 cm -1 for C-C bond stretching for aromatic compounds, 1448cm -1 for C-H bending of alkanes, 1656 cm -1 for C=C bond stretching of alkenes, 2830 cm -1 for C-H stretching of aldehydes, 2945cm -1 for C-H stretching of alkanes, and 3317 cm -1 for terminal C-H stretching of alkanes. Figure 8(b) implies that IR spectrum of the synthesized ZrO2 NPs shows no characteristic peak of organic functional groups which suggests decomposing of organic functional groups due to annealing at high temperature and obtaining pure ZrO2 NPs. Although polyphenols acted as a capping and stabilizing agents, organic moieties were removed from the surfaces after annealing at high temperature.

sections.heading: 3.10 Cytotoxicity evaluations:
sections.text:
The dose-dependent cytotoxic activity of ZrO2 NPs synthesized by using green method
was carried out on two different cancer cell lines i.e. HCT-116 colon cancer and A-549 lung
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
cancer cell lines. The comparative cytotoxic behavior of ZrO2 NPs was tested against these cell lines. The cell viability was analyzed by MTT assay while trypan blue exclusion assay analyzed the cell mortality. The cell viability (Fig. 9a, 9b) and IC50 curves for HCT-116 (Fig. S1) and A549 (Fig. S2) suggest that ZrO2 NPs synthesized by this approach is more toxic to A549 cell lines. It can be noted that ZrO2 NPs are efficiently toxic to both cell lines and has potential in anticancer drug development. The results suggest the cell mortality caused by loss of membrane integrity of the cell lines. Interestingly, the membrane integrity test i.e. trypan blue exclusion assay (Fig. 10a, 10b) and calculated IC50 Curves (Fig.S3-S4) affirmed the results of MTT assay (Fig. 9a, 9b). MTT assay was also performed for non-cancerous Vero cell lines collected from African green monkey kidney epithelial cells. MTT assay results for non-cancerous Vero cell lines are presented in Fig. 11 and the calculated IC50 (50% cell death) is 228 µg/mL (Fig. S5) suggesting lesser toxicity of ZrO2 NPs to normal cell lines. Similar types of results are reported elsewhere using the same Vero cell lines [42-45]. Furthermore, to have a deep insight into the mechanism of action reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation was estimated for control and synthesized ZrO2 NPs at different concentration (50-200 μg/mL) (Fig. 12) by using DCFH2-DA dye assay which confirmed the generation of ROS and related cytotoxicity by bio-synthesized ZrO2 NPs.
It can be noted that as of our knowledge, this is the first study on ZrO2 NPs to find out
exact mechanism of action i.e. loss of membrane integrity which further may be justified by a test to measure reactive oxygen species generation. Though ROS may cause loss of DNA as well as cellular proteins, it has a major role in the loss of membrane integrity [46-52]. In this junction it may be noted that although TGA study (Fig. 5) has demonstrated the loss of capped organic compounds after annealing at high temperature the size of ZrO2 NPs synthesized by this method
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
is about 8-9 nm which is the smallest particles among the particles synthesized by other methods such as chemical combustion [53], phyto-combustion [54], precipitation method [55, 56] and biosynthesis by using fungi Fusarium oxysporium [24] (Table 1). Phytochemical analysis of E. globulus showed the presence of more than thirty compounds such as monoterpenes, sesquiterpenoids triterpene cladacalol, quinic acid,ellagic acid, gallic acid, caffeic acid, chlorogenicacid, methyl gallate, glycosides, p-cymene, ß-pinene, carvacrol,4-terpineol, piperitone, cryptone and phenolic compounds such as thymol, 1,8 cineole [57-59]. Also, Gerike et al. reported that carbonyl group (C=O) of terpenoids or flavanones were adsorbed on the surface of metal NPs which minimized coalescence and during calcination these adsorbed molecules restricted agglomeration resulting smaller sized NPs [60, 61].
Recently, researchers have assessed the cellular toxicity of iron–manganese-doped
sulfated ZrO2 NPs against human colon cancer HT29, human breast cancer MDA-MB231, human liver cancer HepG2 cell lines, Chang liver cell line (CCL-13) and Human Umbilical Vein Endothelial Cells (HUVEC), and the IC50 values are 125.31, 28.06, 41.26, 95.13 and 193.88 µg/mL respectively [5]. Similarly, the cytotoxicity of sulfated ZrO2 NPs was observed against three human cancer cell lines (liver hepatocellular carcinoma HepG2 cells, colon carcinoma HT29 cells, human breast adenocarcinoma cell line MCF-7) and Normal Human Mammary Epithelial Cells (MCF-10a), and the IC50 values are 61.8, 26.4, 89.8 and 151.63 µg/mL [62]. The IC50 values of human colon carcinoma HCT-116 and human lung carcinoma A-549 cell lines are 167.4 and 140.88 µg/mL respectively (Fig. S1-S4) which suggests that the toxicity of NPs depends on cell lines, types of nanopowders, synthesis approaches, capping agents, the sizeshape property of the nanoparticle. The ZrO2 NPs synthesized by this approach was more toxic to human colon carcinoma cells than the human lung carcinoma cells. Based on the results of this
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
study a pictorial demonstration of reactive oxygen species (ROS) mechanism of action for its toxic behavior towards cell lines is presented in Figure 13.

sections.heading: 3.11 Antioxidant activity assay:
sections.text:
In pharmaceutical science as well as nanoscience antioxidant activity plays a key role in
determining IC50 values. Figure 14 reports the percentage of free radical scavenging activity of synthesized ZrO2 NPs in comparison with that of standard ascorbic acid values. The percentage of scavenged DPPH free radical concentration in reaction mixture was calculated by using the formula,
DPPH free radical Scavenging effect (%) = (A0 -At /A0) × 100, DPPH free radical non-scavenging effect (%) = 100-(A0 -At /A0) × 100. Where A0 was absorbance values of the control sample (DPPH) and At is absorbance of
the test sample at different µg/mL concentrations.
ZrO2 NPs exhibited more scavenging inhibition up to 85.6 % capacity with IC50 value of
158.15 µg/mL (Fig. S5), which is higher than that of intracellular extracts of Streptomyces species (JX397877) synthesized ZrO2 NPs (32.34% inhibition) [63] while 71.4% and 76.9% inhibition by nano-zirconia synthesized by chemical method at 1 mg and 100 mg doses respectively [64]. Higher antioxidant activity of ZrO2 NPs is due to the smaller particle size (9.6 nm) and other reason may be decreasing n → π* transition intensity at 517 nm due to the transfer of electron density from oxygen atom present in ZrO2 NPs to odd electron located at nitrogen atom in DPPH molecule. 4.0 Conclusions: The synthesized ZrO2 NPs using the facile green route were monoclinic and cubic phase structured nanoparticles. The ZrO2 NPs were spherical in shape with the size ranging from 9-11
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
nm and high Zeta potential value of -45.5 mV indicated high stability for a longer period of time. The cytotoxic behavior of ZrO2 NPs was confirmed by MTT assay. ROS was responsible for the observed cytotoxic behaviour of ZrO2 NPs. In addition, green synthesized ZrO2 NPs exhibited higher antioxidant activity i.e. up to 85.6% scavenging inhibition of free radicals liberated by DPPH molecule. Further, this proposed methodology may serve as an alternative method for the synthesis of ZrO2 NPs in larger scale and also synthesized NPs will be useful in many potential biomedical applications such as anti-cancer, cytotoxicity via reactive oxygen species generation (ROS) and antioxidant activities.

Nano-Zirconia – evaluation of its antioxidant and anticancer activity
Siripireddy Balaji a , Badal Kumar Mandal a,* Shivendu Ranjan b , Nandita Dasgupta b ,
Ramalingam Chidambaram b
a Trace Elements Speciation Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, School of
Advanced Sciences, VIT University, Vellore 632014, India; b Nano-food Research Group, Instrumental and Food Analysis Laboratory, School of Bio Sciences and Technology, VIT
University, Vellore, Tamil Nadu, India.*The corresponding author
Graphical Abstract
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
Research Highlights:
 Synthesis of smaller size tetragonal nano-ZrO2 by Eucalyptus globulus leaves extract  ZrO2 NPs shows high anti-oxidant activity  ZrO2 NPs are more cytotoxic to A549 compared to HCT116 carcinoma cell lines  ZrO2 NPs can be used as a potential anti-cancer agent

references.title: Eucalyptus globulus Precipitation method Spherical  8-9 Present work  ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT  AC  CE  PT  ED  M  AN  US  CR  IP  T 39  Nano-Zirconia – evaluation of its antioxidant and anticancer activity Siripireddy Balaji
author: Badal Kumar Mandal  a
Shivendu Ranjan  b
Nandita Dasgupta b
Ramalingam

referenceMentions.context: Various chemical methods such as solvothermal method, hydrothermal method [6-10], aqueous precipitation method [11], sol-gel method [12-14], thermal decomposition methods [15-17] and pyrolysis of zirconium oxychloride salt organic precursors have been applied to prepare ZrO2 NPs [18].

metadata.abstractText: Bioactivity of nanomaterials largely depends on its size, shape and crystalline nature. In this work, the smaller sized spherical shaped nano-zirconia (ZrO2 NPs) (of ~ 9 to 11nm) was fabricated and studied its biological activity especially antioxidant and cytotoxicity against human colon carcinoma (HCT-116) and human lung carcinoma (A-549) cell lines. To have its real applications in biological aspects readily available Eucalyptus globulus (E. globulus) leaf extract was used as an effective capping and reducing agent for its synthesis. The prepared ZrO2 NPs was characterized by using different sophisticated instrumentations such as UV-Visible spectrophotometer, XRD, FTIR, TEM, SAED, EDX, DLS and fluorescence spectroscopy. Cellular mitochondrial activity i.e. cell viability was measured by MTT assay and anti-oxidant activity was determined by DPPH assay. The smaller sized ZrO2 NPs showed strong antioxidant activity as well as cytotoxicity on human cancer cell lines. Comparative cytotoxic studies were conducted on human cancerous cell lines using different techniques. Results confirmed the efficient anti-cancer activities of the fabricated ZrO2 NPs towards the tested cell lines as well as efficient anti-oxidant activity. This is the first study in which E. globulus leaf extract was used to synthesize smaller spherical shaped ZrO2 NPs for improved bioactivity i.e. antioxidant and cytotoxicity. ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
